solution.text:
The square root of 3 more than an unknown number can be written in the form of linear equations as
\(\sqrt {y + 3}\) = _{j}_ , where y is the first unknown number.
Square on both sides
\(\Rightarrow\) y+3 = _{j}_ \(\times\) _{j}_
\(\Rightarrow\) y = _{{j*j}}_ - 3
\(\Rightarrow\) y = _{{(j**2)-3}}_
Now,when y is added to the second unknown number z , we get the five times y.
z + y = 5y
z = 4y
z = 4 \(\times\) _{{(j**2)-3}}_
z = _{{4*((j**2)-3)}}_

content.text: The square root of 3 more than an unknown number y is _{j}_. When y is added to another unknown number z we get the five times of the y. What is the value of z ?
